thread.title: Adrian Peterson has Seahawks, Raiders at top of list, RB's dad says
thread.title_full: Adrian Peterson has Seahawks, Raiders at top of list, RB's dad says

author: USA TODAY Sports
title: Adrian Peterson has Seahawks, Raiders at top of list, RB's dad says
text:
Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook Email Adrian Peterson has Seahawks, Raiders at top of list, RB's dad says Ahead of free agency, Adrian Peterson has his eyes on two establish teams. Post to Facebook Adrian Peterson has Seahawks, Raiders at top of list, RB's dad says Ahead of free agency, Adrian Peterson has his eyes on two establish teams.  //usat.ly/2ncuHlo   Join the Nation's Conversation   Adrian Peterson has Seahawks, Raiders at top of list, RB's dad says Michael Middlehurst-Schwartz , USA TODAY Sports Published 9:06 p.m. ET March 7, 2017 | Updated 5 minutes ago CLOSE x Share USA TODAY Sports' Tom Pelissero breaks down the news out of the combine and upcoming free agency. USA TODAY Sports Minnesota Vikings running back Adrian Peterson (28) rushes with the ball in the second half against the Detroit Lions at TCF Bank Stadium. (Photo: Jesse Johnson, USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Adrian Peterson might be zeroing in on two contenders for his potential landing spot ahead of free agency. 
The four-time all-pro running back is most interested in the Seattle Seahawks and Oakland Raiders if he does not return to the Minnesota Vikings, his father told the St. Paul Pioneer Press on Tuesday. 
Seahawks offensive coordinator Darrell Bevell oversaw Peterson and the Vikings' offense from 2006-2010, including the 2009 season in which the running back ran for 2,097 yards. 
“You look at the connections in Seattle, so there’s definitely interest there,” Nelson Peterson told the Pioneer Press . “Those are some pretty good years.” 
MORE COVERAGE: NFL mock draft 3.0: Who's rising after combine? 
Seahawks coach Pete Carroll said at the NFL scouting combine that Thomas Rawls and C.J. Prosise would compete for the starting running back role next season. 
The Raiders emerged as a team of interest thanks to a strong offensive line that features three Pro Bowl selections in offensive tackle Donald Penn, offensive guard Kelechi Osemele and center Rodney Hudson. Starting running back Latavius Murray is set to hit free agency and might not be re-signed. 
The Vikings made Peterson an impending free agent last Tuesday when they announced they would not exercise his $18 million contract option. A return remains possible, Peterson's father said, but the Vikings' approach might have created friction. 
“The Vikings should have come back with a number if you truly want him back,’’ Nelson Peterson said. “I listened to (general manager Rick Spielman say at last week’s NFL scouting combine that), ‘We’ll have to see what the market is?’ If you do want him back, give him a number. Is it $9 million? Is it $8 million? That would have made him feel more appreciated.’’ 
Follow Michael Middlehurst-Schwartz on Twitter @MikeMSchwartz .
